title: good summer read
content: I like this author Kristin Hannah.  I first read “the women” by her, about life for army nurses who served in Vietnam. This book was quite different, about family dynamics. And relationships within the core family. Sometimes you don’t understand what you think that you know.

title: A TYPICAL  SUMMER READ
content: I MUST BE MISSING SOMETHING. . . .I THOUGHT THAT DEAN WAS THE BROTHER OF RUBY AND CAROLINE.  COME TO FIND OUT, HE WAS JUST A NEIGHBOR. . . .A "CRUSH" THAT RUBY HAD.  ANYWAY, AFTER I FIGURED IT ALL OUT, IT WAS AN OK READ.  TYPICAL STUFF.  NOT THE BEST BY ANY MEANS
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 15, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: I have read a number of Kristin Hannah's novels and enjoyed every one.  She is an excellent storyteller and I love that her books are long.  By the end, you feel like the characters are friends.  What I don't appreciate and the reason for my four star rating rather than a five star is her extreme use of foul language.  I am a Christian and the language is offensive to me.  I feel as if the stories would be just as powerful without the language.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2023

title: Excellent Storyteller
content: Absolutely awesome book. How does she get into the minds of her characters so well. I could hardly out this down. I loved and hated and all the characters all the way. Thank you. And a happily ever after, too— I’m hoping!

title: Growing up in love
content: This is a story about the estranged relationship between a mother and daughter. Nora Bridge is a well-known and respected advice columnist  and radio talk show host who is always espousing the importance of family. In reality, Nora and her own daughter haven't spoken in years.  Ruby Bridge is a struggling standup comic who's stand-up routine consists of telling stinging jokes about the mother who abandoned her.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 8, 2016

title: Verified Purchase
content: Things change when Nora's fans turn against her after a secret in her past is made public by a would-be blackmailer. When Nora is hurt in a car accident, she flees to the family summer cottage to recover from her injuries and get away from the tabloid press. When Ruby surprisingly volunteers to come to the summer cottage to take care of her mother while she recovers, Nora is hopeful this will lead to a reconciliation with her daughter.  What Nora doesn't know is that Ruby has accepted $50,000 to write a "tell all" magazine article about her mother.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 28, 2024

title: Forgiveness and moving forward
content: This sounds like the makings of a good story (and I haven't even mentioned the rekindling of a childhood romance storyline, or the childhood friend who is now dying storyline). The book isn't bad, but it did fall a bit flat for me. It probably didn't help that Ruby isn't the most sympathetic character.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: "Summer Island" was not nearly as compelling a story as Kristin Hannah's "The Nightingale", an historical fiction about two sisters during the Second World War.  Nor was it as enjoyable a read as "Firefly Lane", about two best friends during the Seventies, Eighties and Nineties. I think this book deserves 3.5 stars, but I'm rounding up because of the goodwill left over from prior books I've read by this author. And because I look forward to reading another Kristin Hannah book soon.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 9, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: This was an emotive and beautiful tale of a Family. The realities of life, with all its glory and flaws.  Especially now, in these times when everyone is so deeply opinionated about politics and religion, it’s a great reminder about what matters most.  Love matters most.  Forgive and remember that time is fleeting.  Except your differences and be kind.  That’s all.

title: gripping
content: This one has it all - I laughed, cried, and mused.  Made me think about the reality of life, and the flaws in each of us. And how when we seek to understand (rather than judge) we learn so much. We learn about ourselves.

post_time: Reviewed in the United States on January 13, 2023

title: Summer Island
content: I think what I liked most about this book was that it celebrated the fact that families don’t have to be perfect to be wonderful.  The contrast between the original version of the Bridge family and the mess it became after several years of decisions, assumptions, mistakes and failures is stark.  The peeling back of those layers is at the same time painful and poignantly beautiful.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on February 3, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: One thing is for sure, we are shaped by our childhood, but we get to choose to be better people when we are adults. This book explores so many facets of how to become a more balanced mature person from so many angles.  I really enjoyed it.
